body: A Brooklyn church has found a way to ease its financial problems through a novel arrangement with a Queens developer that allows it to keep a room in the rear of its building for worship services while the developer converts the main sanctuary into luxury apartments and medical offices. title: CHURCH MAKES NOVEL DEAL WITH DEVELOPER

body: Economics have finally caught up with the 131-year-old South Congregational Church in the Carroll Gardens Section of Brooklyn. Faced with a $9,000 heating bill this coming winter, the tiny congregation, who number about 20 on Sunday, have accepted an offer from Jean G. Miele, a Queens developer, to convert the three-story sanctuary into luxury
title: POSTINGS; 'ELITISM'?

body: The left bank of the Gowanus Canal, an unlovely piece of real estate in South Brooklyn, seems hardly the most propitious site for an outdoor art show. Yet there, at Smith and Fifth Streets, on a five-acre former dump rife with weeds, trash middens and expired auto bodies, blooms the Gowanus Memorial Art Yard. A city-owned facility preempted for the
title: GALLERY VIEW; DRAWING A BEAD ON PUBLIC MONUMENTS

body: More than 350 courses in women's studies at 53 educational institutions and women's centers throughout the city are included in a new publication from the New York City Commission on the Status of Women. title: COURSES FOR WOMEN IN THE CITY

body: Barbara Blair's first New York apartment was a railroad flat with one tiny bedroom that she shared with a roommate. ''There was no privacy,'' she said, ''but it was nothing like my second apartment, which was a horror.'' It fronted on Second Avenue, over a restaurant, and although it had two bedrooms, she had to go through her roommate's bedroom to
title: FOR CITY'S YOUNG, THE LIVING IS NOT EASY

body: New York City school officials are increasingly concerned over the fate of thousands of youngsters who may have to repeat the seventh grade several times before raising their reading scores high enough to be promoted. A strict new promotion policy requires the public schools to hold back seventh-grade pupils until they pass the reading test. The
title: RULE TYING PUPIL PROMOTION TO READING SKILL STIRS WORRY

body: THIS is a tough year to look for an apartment or a house in New YorkC ity, but it is also a year of opportunity. The availability of r ental apartments remains low - the vacancy rate was 2.l3 percent at t he most recent count - and high mortgage rates are forcing up the c ost of cooperatives, condominiums and houses. title: A HOMESEEKER'S GUIDE TO THE CITY

body: THE woman is talking. The doctor is taking notes. ''I live in an apartment the size of my high school locker,'' she i s saying. ''The garbage trucks outside my window at 3 A.M. sound l ike an accident at Indian Point. The super won't fix anything, and m y rent is $600 a month. A methadone clinic is moving in downstairs.
